section.title: Introduction
section.para: The &atd; job execution system allows users to schedule one-time running jobs. The at.allow file specifies a list of users that are allowed to schedule jobs via &atd;. The file does not exist by default, so all users can schedule &atd; jobs—except for those listed in at.deny)

listitem.para: You have installed your product and your system is up and running.
The at package is installed. If not, run zypper in at to install it.

section.title: Troubleshooting
section.para: When implementing /etc/at.allow, there are basically only two problems that can occur:

varlistentry.term: A user can schedule a job with &atd; although they should not.

listitem.para: Check that the username in /etc/at.allow matches the actual username.

varlistentry.term: A user can not schedule a job with &atd; jobs although they should.

listitem.para: If the user is correctly listed in /etc/at.allow but cannot schedule &atd; jobs, check if they are also listed in /etc/at.deny. If the user appears in both files, /etc/at.deny wins. Remove the user from that file to allow them to schedule &atd; jobs.
&atd; is not widely used anymore. If you do not have valid use cases, consider uninstalling the daemon instead of just restricting its access.
To further improve security, also consider restricting access to the &crond; daemon.
